> change LGTM. But quick question: if topic doesn't have subscribers and publishers, then why do we want to keep inactive topic till message-retention time?

I can see multiple reasons : 
 * Consistency & semantic: If I configure the retention for 3h, I should have the data stored for (at least) 3h, irrespective of other conditions 
 * Retention is used primarily to be able to roll-back a consumer. Right now it's possible to create a subscription (at the end of the stream) and then roll it back to a earlier point in time, but only if there are already other subscriptions, otherwise the topic would have been deleted before.
 * Using the Reader API, the broker doesn't control the reader position, so, when a reader is gone it doesn't retain anything on the broker side. The reader relies on the retention for the data to be available and it's vital to not delete the topic before that time expires.

Fixed in #648

I think the entire parameter value should be parsed on plugins side. Then plugins can choose any format they want. Some plugin may need just a keyword, some other may need binary data. This would break compatibility though. I'd say the current interface could be better. (When can we make incompatible changes btw?)

If we need to keep compatibility as possible as we can, 4th option would be "Encode values" (== don't allow to use ":" and ","). Any encodings which doesn't use ":" and "," (e.g. base64, URL encode) are fine, and we can (should) delegate the decoding to plugins.

I don't know much about athenz but why is this needed? What would be the benefits?

If we provide multiple ways to achieve something,  we should provide their pros and cons too so that users can make a right decision. Otherwise it would introduce confusion.
Fix confirmed, thanks.

In case of PCF, we should not deploy private key as a file in terms of security and auto scale, we should set private key content to Environment variable.
so we added this modification and we think this is useful in the similar case.

So, created #676 , and hopefully it should fix it.

OK, that makes sense. Since it's just a plugin I don't object introducing its own unique way, however, it sounds like not athenz specific issue. The same issue will appear if somebody tried to use TLS auth, and they would need to re-implement the logic to read secrets from somewhere. Also, all users who read it from environment variables need to implement the logic even though it's not an unique way.

How about adding support for URL schemes (e.g. file:, data:, env:, exec:) to privateKeyPath config param? If we provided the reader and plugins used it, the plugins would get the same benefit when we support new scheme (new data source), plus it can be applicable for any configuration parameters.

> How about adding support for URL schemes (e.g. file:, data:, env:, exec:) to privateKeyPath config param? If we provided the reader and plugins used it, the plugins would get the same benefit when we support new scheme (new data source), plus it can be applicable for any configuration parameters.

+1 for this. In container deployements line Kubernetes, it is common to have private key in files that are mounted as "secrets" and seen as files by the application.
OK. We will consider it.

#678 fixes this.
#678 fixes this.
Merged #678
Merged #678

I haven't found a way to fix this. We are using the `ReflectionFactory` in tests to instantiate a Zookeeper client instance without invoking the constructor (in the `MockZookeeper`).

Not calling the constructor is critical because `Zookeeper` class is trying to do many thing (like connecting) from the constructor and there is no other interface.

> I still see a warning below. Are you going to fix this too on this PR?

Fixing this is not straightforward. I think the best option is to get rid of `RecyclableSlicedByteBuf` and upgrade to Netty 4.1 which has something very similar to it. (I actually submitted a PR with the first version of it and then it got improved and merged there). 
Anyway, we should use `buffer.retainedSlice()` and `buffer.retainedDuplicate()`
https://netty.io/4.1/api/io/netty/buffer/ByteBuf.html#retainedSlice--

> [WARNING] /Users/masakazu/git/pulsar/pulsar-common/src/main/java/io/netty/buffer/RecyclableSlicedByteBuf.java:[69,37] [deprecation] DuplicatedByteBuf in io.netty.buffer has been deprecated
> Also, I'm curious why the class is under netty namespace. Is it because of accessibility (package-private)?

Yes, the `RecyclableSlicedByteBuf` is kind of a "hack" to force recycling of duplicate buffers and needs to access internal Netty methods which are package protected.

> Anyway, we should use buffer.retainedSlice() and buffer.retainedDuplicate()
https://netty.io/4.1/api/io/netty/buffer/ByteBuf.html#retainedSlice--

That doesn't sound like a small change. Let's do it separately.

We may be able to get rid of RecyclableSlicedByteBuf if we upgrade Netty to 4.1.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/679#issuecomment-321988130
retest this please

@maskit 
> I think the entire parameter value should be parsed on plugins side. Then plugins can choose any format they want. 

Thank you for your comments and I agree.
Then, how about modifying by 2 steps?

Step 1.
Add URL-decoding logic to C++ Athenz plugin (Morespecifically, ZTSClient.cc):
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client-cpp/lib/auth/athenz/ZTSClient.cc#L76
This change keeps the compatibility.

Step 2.
Move parsing logic from `AuthenticationFactory` to each Authentication plugin.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/api/AuthenticationFactory.java#L44-L53
This change breaks the compatibility.

I think it's a kind of incompatible change. Old version users will be surprised if they don't migrate their configurations.

Should we land this on 1.20? We should probably make it clear what won't change on 1.x releases.

> I think it's a kind of incompatible change. Old version users will be surprised if they don't migrate their configurations.

Yes, may be we can document the change. However, one thing to note is broker doesn't depend on `log4j2` explicitly and it loads this lib at run time as log4j2-lib gets bundled as part of binaries. 
so, if anyone depends directly on binary-bundle and uses default log-config then log4j will be replaced by log4j2 without any impact and 
if one has explicit logging-configuration and using explicit lib-packaging then they will keep using old log4j dependency only without any change so, the may not be impacted.

> Should we land this on 1.20? We should probably make it clear what won't change on 1.x releases.

yes, we can decide if we want to take as part of 1.20 or later releases with proper notice in documentation. @merlimat  any thought on it?

I think it's ok to switch to log4j-2.x in 1.20. 

Even though there are (potentially) some actions to take on the upgrade, I don't think it's the same as breaking the APIs (which would require a version 2.x for Pulsar). Speaking of which we already just broke the API in 1.20, by switching to `org.apache.pulsar` package names.

In this case, no code changes or anything else is needed, just configuration change if you have custom rules.

We just should document that in the release notes: "if you have custom logging configuration, you should update your log4j conf files". Maybe we could even create an entry in the Wiki to which we can refer from the release notes.

Note: there are now deprecation warnings on the Protobuf generated code, though I'd rather address them in a separate PR, since it will have to change the `protobuf.patch` that we have. 
```
[WARNING] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/pulsar-pull-request/pulsar-common/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/common/api/proto/PulsarApi.java:[289,42] [deprecation] recycle(T,Handle<T>) in Recycler has been deprecated
```

> In this case, no code changes or anything else is needed, just configuration change if you have custom rules.

Right, there is one case people cannot simply upgrade. I'm worried about this "Oops" case. I guess many people don't read release notes when they update packages because they know (or expect) that new version works without any changes as long as they use the same major version. Not a few packages make it possible by running migration scripts during installation or keeping compatibility strictly through one major version. Without any of these, "Oops" happens. It's not our fault but I don't think it's user friendly.

> We just should document that in the release notes: "if you have custom logging configuration, you should update your log4j conf files". Maybe we could even create an entry in the Wiki to which we can refer from the release notes.

As I wrote above, I think documentation is not enough if we are going to land this on 1.20. Any idea to avoid running new version without existing custom rules? It would be a good safety.

We discussed support of URL scheme and we will implement it by the following:

Add new field(``privateKey``) to Athenz client plugin's authParams and this fields support URL scheme(``file:`` and ``data:``).

following three patterns are supported:
```
file:/path/to/file
file:///path/to/file

// application/x-pem-file;base64, is fixed.
data:application/x-pem-file;base64,<base64-encoded value>
```

Also, We will deprecate ``privateKeyPath`` field.


If there is anything that concerns you, please tell me.
PR #703 is for the fix.

My name is Yuta Takaba, a software engineer at Yahoo Japan Corporation.
Please call me **TKB**!
Anyway, I try to address this issue by the following:

1: Adding `configure(String authParamString)` to [Authentication](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/api/Authentication.java) instead of making new interface for simplicity

2: Support JSON for configure.
   - Because, JSON is popular, widely used.
   - For keeping compatibility, using current parsing logic(separated by “:” and “,”)  if an argument is not JSON.

What about having an `unload-topic` API handler? That would make it easier then first figuring out the bundle and then unloading the bundle.
Also, if you just care about a specific topic, you might want to unload it alone, rather than whole bundle.

> What about having an unload-topic API handler? 

Yes, that can be useful. But we see need of bundle-range api in multiple cases
1. we know specific topic having high traffic and we want to know bundle of that topic so, we can split. right now, we don't have any direct tool to find out bundle-range for the topic.
2. as explained above, sometime we have list of topics with high traffic, so, we want to get list of bundles and based on analysis we want to unload specific bundle.

We wouldn't say "It's OK because API is still compatible." if the configuration file was for pulsar-broker/client/plugins. Can we say "Hey users, we've fixed many bugs! Update your config file, or keep using buggy version!" ? I'd say no.

One thing that makes this topic difficult is probably that we don't have a plan for 2.0 release. We may release it in a few months or a few years. I guess we all would agree on postponing this to 2.0 if it was going to be released soon.

Java 9 will be released in September, and we are trying to upgrade Netty and our C++ client too. I think releasing 2.0 with this change in October or November is a reasonable option.

Edit
Instead of new API we can just add the retry count as a part of client configuration.
Creating producer/consumer has already retry logic for transient errors. The retry is done with exponential backoff delays up to the configured `operationTimeout`, which is by default 30s.

To the best of my knowledge - the reconnection logic triggers only once the connection is established atleast once:-
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/HandlerBase.java#L113

What I want is that we try to retry even if we are unable to establish the connection the first time due to intermittent failures leading to getPartitionedTopicMetadata to fail. In other words, I want to add a for loop here:- 
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/PulsarClientImpl.java#L159

> To the best of my knowledge - the reconnection logic triggers only once the connection is established atleast once:-

If that's the case it would be a bug :)

It should be easy to have a unit test to show it. Create the producer asynchronously, then bring up the broker within few seconds and verify the producer gets created correctly.
